G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 28A.proposition: The Plaintiff, Maria Torres, respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 28A, seeking a modification of the custody and parenting time arrangement for the parties’ minor child, Sophia Carter.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28;.proposition: A Complaint for Modification may be allowed where there is a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the existing Judgment and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 30.proposition: A Complaint for Modification may be allowed where there is a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the existing Judgment and where modification is in the child’s best interests.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 30.support_reasoning: The case is an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, not a post-judgment Complaint for Modification. The opinion discusses best-interest standards and the need for detailed findings regarding domestic violence but does not address the legal standard for allowing a modification, nor does it refer to a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since an existing judgment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated modification proposition.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 30.relevant_excerpt: “Neither G. L. c. 209C, § 10(c)… nor G. L. c. 208, § 31… specify or enumerate factors which must or should be considered in determining custody… custody orders and judgments are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child, and the statutes leave it to the trial judge to identify and weigh any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the specific dispute. ‘A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the child.’”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183-8.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child in a modification action, the Court considers the effect of a proposed change on the child’s stability and overall well-being.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183-8.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the governing standard as the “best interests” of the children and explains that this requires taking into account “all the circumstances,” including the effect of relocation on the children’s current school situation, the disruption from uprooting them, and the impact on their relationship with the father. These are stability and well-being factors. The court then applies that standard to deny removal because the move would be “detrimental” and “negatively affect” the children, particularly in light of the older child’s special needs and existing support system.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183-8.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests….”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that relocation and geographic distance can constitute a material change in circumstances.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Yannas concerns the legal standard for permitting removal of a child from Massachusetts in the first instance (the “real advantage” test and best-interests analysis). It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or visitation order based on relocation, nor does it characterize relocation or geographic distance as a “material change in circumstances” for purposes of post-judgment modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about material change in circumstances.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent …” (395 Mass. at 710–11).

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Parenting time schedules that interfere with a child’s ability to maintain a consistent routine, attend school, or participate in extracurricular activities are contrary to the child’s best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on removal standards, custody modification, and weighing the interests of the custodial and noncustodial parents under Yannas and Hale. While it briefly notes that removal might ‘interrupt’ the child’s education, the Appeals Court rejects that as a sufficient basis to deny removal and does not articulate any general rule that parenting time schedules interfering with routine, school, or activities are contrary to a child’s best interests. The case therefore does not establish or endorse the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Finding no. 54: “Removal . . . would pose as an unnecessary interruption to this child’s otherwise steady and promising education.” … The probate judge concluded that “The Mother has not provided any evidence which is tantamount to finding such a removal would be an improvement upon this child’s life. The evidence indicates that such removal would be disruptive to this child’s life.” We first note that it was not the mother’s burden to provide evidence of improvement, but that the factors must be considered collectively.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Parenting time schedules that interfere with a child’s ability to maintain a consistent routine, attend school, or participate in extracurricular activities are contrary to the child’s best interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation under a general ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does not address parenting time schedules interfering with a child’s routine, schooling, or extracurricular activities. The visitation discussion focuses on parental conflict and incidents such as substandard hygiene, not on the impact of the schedule on the children’s daily structure or activities. Therefore, it does not supply authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”
